Different Crime.Crime Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
legal_basis: Section 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
evidence_assessment: accepted evidence of violence against Hindus in Bangladesh but found it insufficient to prove personal risk or generalized oppression affecting the Applicant
procedural_fairness: Judicial review of the Pre-Removal Risk Assessment decision based on new evidence submitted by the Applicant
refugee_definition: Applicant claimed refugee status due to fear of persecution as a Hindu woman in Bangladesh
reasonableness_of_decision: Officer's decision was reasonable and did not misapply the legal test under IRPA

burden_of_proof: Applicants failed to prove reviewable error

legal_basis: Affidavits should not be struck unless they are abusive, irrelevant, or contain inadmissible evidence. Admissibility issues are better assessed by the trial judge.
evidence_assessment: Admissibility issues are better assessed by the trial judge.
application_details: The affidavits include collateral evidence and public documents, which may support the applicants' case.
decision_reasoning: Striking them entirely would prematurely resolve complex admissibility questions.
procedure_followed: Motion hearing where both parties argued the relevance and admissibility of affidavits in a judicial review context.
result_of_case: Motion denied; trial judge will decide on admissibility without prejudice.
